Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High Strength, Surface Porous Devices for Improved Spinal Fusions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a novel high strength, surface porous layer that can improve integration of non-metal orthopedic implants, resulting in better clinical outcomes. This improvement to orthopedic implants is especially important for lumbar fusion devices, which are used to alleviate chronic back and leg pain in over 240,000 patients annually. Non-metal, polymer implants are most commonly used for lumbar fusions because of their compatibility with medical imaging. However, these devices have smooth surfaces that do not integrate well with bone, which leads to a complication and revision surgery rate of approximately 11 to 15%.

The proposed project will investigate the feasibility of the high strength, surface porous layer for use on lumbar fusion cages. The research objectives are to determine the effect the architecture of the surface porous layer has on the mechanical properties and the biological response for improved bone integration. The research will use standard mechanical tests to determine the static and fatigue properties of different polymer constructs with the surface porous layer and to determine the mechanical properties of the surface porous layer itself. Additionally, the research will use cell studies to determine the effect the porous layer architecture has on improving the osteoconductive response of cells to the implant surface. Finally, devices with the surface layer will be prototyped and tested under physiological conditions. It is anticipated that the architecture will have a minimal effect on bulk mechanical properties while significantly improving the osteoconductive response.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Degenerative disc disease affects more than 60% of individuals over the age of 40 with approximately 70% of all cases occurring in the lower back, where decreased disc height pinches nerve roots emanating from the spinal cord, resulting in disabling back and leg pain. To restore disc height, total disc arthroplasty, disc repair, and spinal fusion procedures are performed; however total disc arthroplasty and disc repair have well documented ineffectiveness, resulting in minimal reimbursement and clinical uptake in the U.S. Therefore, spinal fusion using an interbody fusion device to provide biomechanical support and restore disc height is the clinical gold standard for alleviating chronic back pain. Each year, over 240,000 lumbar fusion procedures are performed at an estimated cost of $4.2 billion dollars. Despite this high clinical adoption, approximately 11 to 15% of all lumbar fusions results in complications or non-unions that require revision surgery. Since it is estimated that 1% of all fusion failures cost the U.S. $110 million annually, there is a significant need to improve lumbar fusions.

To decrease surrounding tissue damage and associated complications, minimally invasive surgery (MIS) in the lower back is becoming a more prevalent option. Devices are manufactured from different materials (e.g. PEEK, titanium, porous tantalum, machined bone), PEEK (a type of high strength plastic) devices in “bullet” and “banana” shapes are used in over 50% of all MIS fusions because their shape is compatible with MIS insertion, they can endure the loading conditions of the lower back, and are compatible with radiographs, CT, and MRI. However, commercially available PEEK devices are smooth at the cellular level and cannot support bone tissue ingrowth into the device surface. Previously, metal and porous metal cages have been used to promote bone ingrowth into the device to facilitate fusion. However, the metal devices are not compatible with x-ray, CT, or MRI to assess fusion.

The Small Business Innovation Research grant developed a high-strength, porous surface PEEK lumbar cage that acts as a scaffold for bone ingrowth during spinal fusion (Figure 1). Using a new plastic processing method, the porous layer is “extruded” out from the surface of the solid plastic part, which ensures the high strength connection between the solid core and the porous surface.  The extruded porous surface acts as scaffold for increasing bony tissue ingrowth, which will decrease the likelihood of device migration, expulsion, and failed fusion. Due to an all-PEEK device, surgeons will be able to directly visualize bony tissue ingrowth directly into the device surface using MRI or CT scans. The mechanical properties will be strong enough to support bony tissue ingrowth, but be compliant enough to decrease subsidence. Because the bulk properties of the extruded porous PEEK will remain intact, devices made with this processing method will continue to withstand loading conditions in the lower back. The intellectual merit stems from two material innovations: (1) a novel processing technique that can directly extrude porous layers from solid polymer constructs without affecting the bulk mechanical properties and (2) a new material platform that can be tailored to biologically promote implant integration. This project has the potential to broadly impact (1) patients with lower back pain by improving fusion rates while providing imaging capacity to assess bony tissue ingrowth directly into the implant surface and (2) medical devices by providing a broad base of improved orthopaedic implants outside of spine.

The Phase I efforts were successful for each of the primary objectives: (1) The size of the porogen did not have an effect on the mechanical properties, and the surface porous layer has mechanical properties (compression, shear, torsion...
